G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the Plaintiff’s claims arise under Massachusetts law, and the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the Defendant conducts business in Middlesex County, and the events giving rise to this action occurred within Middlesex County.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners owe a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain their premises in a condition that does not present an unreasonable risk of harm to lawful visitors.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that, abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction, property owners owe the same obligation of reasonable care for snow and ice hazards as for all other hazards to lawful visitors. It repeatedly frames the governing standard as a duty to use reasonable care to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors, which directly matches the proposition. The case is therefore proper authority for that general Massachusetts premises-liability duty standard.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.” … “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973).
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.proposition: A failure to correct known hazardous conditions or to take reasonable measures to inspect and remedy potentially dangerous conditions constitutes negligence.
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the duty of a possessor of business premises to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe or to warn of dangers the defendant knows or ought to know about, and discusses liability where a foreign substance remains long enough that the defendant should have discovered and removed it. While the court ultimately finds the evidence insufficient on the time element and orders judgment for the defendant, its articulation of the governing standard recognizes that failure to discover and correct a hazardous condition that should have been found and remedied through reasonable inspection constitutes negligence.
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. … In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

See *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 14.proposition: Where harm is foreseeable, a business owner may be held liable for injuries resulting from unsafe conditions, including improperly secured merchandise.
See *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 14.support_reasoning: The case is about a residential landowner’s premises liability, not a business owner’s duty. It holds that a landowner may owe a duty to remedy even an open and obvious danger that he created and maintained where he can or should anticipate lawful entrants will encounter it, but it does not discuss commercial premises or ‘improperly secured merchandise.’ The proposition mischaracterizes the opinion by shifting from landowner to business owner and from a trampoline–pool setup to merchandise-related hazards.
See *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 14.relevant_excerpt:
“A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg…

Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool…for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool…. On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780 (2007),
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Defendant had a duty under *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780 (2007), to take reasonable precautions to protect customers from known or foreseeable dangers created by unsafe stacking of merchandise.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts the mode of operation approach and holds that where a store’s chosen mode of operation makes it reasonably foreseeable that a dangerous condition will occur, the owner may be liable if it fails to take reasonable precautions to protect invitees from such foreseeable dangers. Although the facts concern grapes on the floor, the court explicitly discusses negligent marketing and display of produce and frames the duty as taking reasonable measures commensurate with risks inherent in the store’s self-service merchandising. That reasoning directly supports a duty to take reasonable precautions against known or foreseeable dangers from unsafe stacking or display of merchandise.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Courts adopting this approach have concluded that where an owner’s chosen mode of operation makes it reasonably foreseeable that a dangerous condition will occur, a store owner could be held liable for injuries to an invitee if the plaintiff proves that the store owner failed to take all reasonable precautions necessary to protect invitees from these foreseeable dangerous conditions… Additionally, a store owner will be liable to a plaintiff injured as a result of a dangerous condition caused by a third party only if the owner could reasonably foresee that the dangerous condition could occur… and the owner took inadequate steps to forestall resulting injuries.”

See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (.proposition: Plaintiff, as an invitee, was entitled to the highest duty of care under Massachusetts law.
See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (.support_reasoning: The excerpt shows that the court in Mounsey rejected the traditional invitee/licensee distinction and moved toward a unified standard of care based on broader negligence principles. Thus, although the proposition assumes the continued relevance of "invitee" status and a distinct "highest duty of care," the opinion instead undermines that categorization rather than affirming it. The case does not support the idea that plaintiff, *as an invitee*, was owed a uniquely highest duty under Massachusetts law.
See *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

See *Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth.*.raw_text: See *Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth.*, 443 Mass. 697 (2005).
See *Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth.*.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes damages for physical and emotional harm caused by a defendant’s negligence.
See *Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth.*.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly assumes and applies the principle that damages are recoverable for both physical and emotional harm caused by a defendant’s negligence. The court affirms that Carmen may recover for physical and emotional injuries from the May 18 attack, and then focuses on whether Samuel and Carmen meet the doctrinal requirements for negligent infliction of emotional distress, confirming that such emotional-distress damages are recognized under Massachusetts negligence law. Thus, the case supports the general proposition that Massachusetts law allows damages for physical and emotional harm resulting from negligence.
See *Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth.*.relevant_excerpt: “The Cambridge Housing Authority (CHA) has not claimed in this appeal that Carmen was not entitled to recover damages for both the physical injuries and emotional distress she suffered as a result of the May 18 home invasion. We have stated that ‘[w]here plaintiffs have suffered directly inflicted personal injuries as a result of a defendant’s negligence, courts have not been reluctant to allow recovery for emotional distress, occurring contemporaneously with those personal injuries, as an additional element of damages.’ Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 548 (1982).”

See *Lindstrom v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 41.raw_text: See *Lindstrom v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 504 (1996).
See *Lindstrom v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 41.proposition: A business owes an active duty to inspect and prevent risks within its premises when merchandise is stored in ways that create hazardous conditions for customers.
See *Lindstrom v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 41.support_reasoning: The opinion text provided is not Lindstrom v. Stop & Shop, Inc., but a psychiatrist‑malpractice/limitations case involving therapist‑patient sexual misconduct. It deals exclusively with the discovery rule and accrual of malpractice and related tort claims, not premises liability, business duties to customers, or inspection of merchandise. Because the case does not address a business’s duty to inspect or prevent hazards from stored merchandise, it does not support the stated proposition.
See *Lindstrom v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 41.relevant_excerpt: “In Riley v. Presnell, 409 Mass, at 240, the Supreme Judicial Court determined that ‘the so-called “discovery rule” affects the accrual of a malpractice action against a psychotherapist’ and held that a statute of limitations does not begin to run in such an action ‘until the plaintiff knew or reasonably should have known that [she] may have suffered injury because of the psychotherapist’s conduct.’”
